prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In 3 basebands we have used the wideband FDM mode. This is essential to remove strong spectral lines from the continuum. These targets are relatively line rich and we expect line widths of several km/s. Thus the ~3.4 km/s spectral resolution afforded by this setup will be adequate to detect and remove contaminating line emission. Additionally there may be a few lines that show significant ouflow emission up to several 10s of km/s wide (SO, HC3N) for which this spectral resolution will also allow detailed mapping. To reduce the data rate, we set the spectral averaging to 2 for these 3 wideband windows since this does not affect the final velocity resolution.
We also placed 2 narrow spws in the 4th baseband to cover 7 hyperfine transitions of CN (1-0). The expected line width for these transitions is expected to be 2-3 km/s. The velocity resolution for these narrow spws is 0.37 km/s, adequate to resolve the lines.

A key goal of this proposal is to spatially resolve the cluster members. The typical separation of massive cluster members is ~5000 AU. The range of distances to the ALMA EGO sample is 1.13 to 4.8 kpc. Thus an angular resolution of 1" provides a resolution better than 4800 AU for all of the targets and an improvment in beam area of a factor of 7 (on average) over our existing SMA 1.3mm data which will be a significant jump forward. A related goal to resolving the cluster members is to characterize their SEDs using Bands 3 and 6. This demands that we obtain comparable uv-coverage at both Bands 3 and 6.
The other key science goal is to simultaneously spatially resolve the molecular outflows (to pinpoint the exciting sources and hence outflow size scale) and to accurately measure the full velocity extent of the outflow gas. Both of these are key to calculating the amount of outflow feedback. Based on the SMA data, we expect that the outflows will extend over much of the 60" extents of the mosaics, see Figure 2 (we will have 80" extent to 50% sensitivity), but we do not expect to see smooth structures larger than ~15" in extent. These two goals, coupled with the expected complex emission require a wide range of spatial scales to achieve good image fidelity. Outflow tracers with a wide range of excitation, optical depth, and critical density have been selected in Bands 3 and 6 so that all parts of the outflows can be detected. Thus for this goal as well, comparable uv-coverage is needed for both bands.
The following array combinations give the requisite and comparable range of spatial scales: Band 3: C36-4 (1" resolution, naturally-weighted) combined with C36-1 (LAS 25.3") Band 6: C36-2 (1" resolution, naturally-weighted) combined with 7m-array (LAS 18.6")

For Band 3, we would like to resolve the emission in each of the "bright" SMA 1.3 mm sources of size ~5" coincident with the EGOs. The peak intensities at 1.3 mm for a 3.2"x2.2" beam are given in Table 2. We would like to independently detect the sources in the upper and lower sidebands of the Band 3 setup in order to better constrain the SED. For the LSB the bandwidth is 2x1.875 GHz, of which we assume 75% will be line-free for a LSBcont_BW=2.8 GHz at 100.5 GHz. In USB there is 1x1.875*75%, or USBcont_BW=1.4GHz at 111.5 GHz. Assuming a 1" beam, and a very conservative assumption of Gaussian emission, the observed ALMA peak emission will be less by the reduction in beam area: 7 (the same reduction holds if the source instead breaks up into 7 pieces - a more likely scenario given past experience than the sources being single Gaussians at the SMA resolution). Assuming the most conservative B3 to B6 spectral index of 4 (only dust, beta=2) the reduction factor for LSB is 28 and for USB 18. Together these assumptions yield at minimum an 8sigma detection in B3 LSB for the weakest of the EGOs in the sample (SMA 1.3mm peak 114 mJy/beam, G18.89-0.47).
Additionally, at the sensitivity level of the current SMA data, most of the EGOs also show a few weaker, much more compact 1.3mm sources in the FOV, with peak intensities of ~20 mJy/beam. These are much less likely to break up into multiple sources as they are already unresolved in the SMA beam. Scaling only by the factor of 28 for the B3 LSB dust spectral index, we predict typical B3 LSB intensities of 0.7 mJy/beam or S/N~10sigma. Thus, we should also be able to reach compact sources at 5 sigma as weak as 0.35 mJy/beam at 101.5 GHz.
The requested B3 sensitivity is driven by the continuum considerations above. However, we also put two narrow spws that cover 7 CN (1-0) hyperfine transitions. This is ancillary science that will allow us to determine the basic properties of the CN emission (peak emission location within the mosaic and linewidth) to prepare for future ALMA Zeeman magnetic field observations. With an assumed spectral resolution of 0.5 km/s, the spectral rms will be 11.3 mJy/beam or 1.1 K. This will be adequate to detect the expected CN line peak emission of ~10 K. Additionally, the emission from the 7 hyperfine transitions can be combined for improved sensitivity.

The datarate is only slightly above 12 MB/s (12.21 MB/s). As described above, the requested level of spectral resolution is needed to resolve the lines and for the continuum to remove the line contamination. A factor of 2 spectral averaging has been selected since that does not impact the velocity resolution.

The correlator has been configured to cover in one tuning as many shock/outflow tracing lines in Band 6 as possible. The simultaneous observation of 12CO and 13CO requires that they be observed with narrow spws. Even so, their bandwidth (300 km/s) is wide enough to encompass the extent of CO emission, see Table 1. However, it is notable that this narrow width precludes the most efficient observing scheme -- only sources with very similar LSRK velocities can be observed together due to this narrow bandwidth. An additional narrow spw with 0.4 km/s channels covers N2D+ which for lower mass sources in the clusters may be as narrow as a few km/s. Two 1.875 GHz wide spws cover other shock tracing lines, most importantly SiO, H2CO, SO, CH3OH, HC3N. We expect that the shock tracing lines will be about 10 km/s wide locally, though spanning many 10s of km/s in full extent. We plan to image the shock tracing lines with 2.5 km/s resolution to provide four spectral elements across local shock features. Lines that can trace the thermal gas in the core like C18O can be imaged at the best spectral resolution of ~1.5 km/s which will be adequate based on our existing ammonia data (see Figure 1).

A key goal of this proposal is to spatially resolve the cluster members. The typical separation of massive cluster members is ~5000 AU. The range of distances to the ALMA EGO sample is 1.13 to 4.8 kpc. Thus an angular resolution of 1" provides a resolution better than 4800 AU for all of the targets and an improvment in beam area of a factor of 7 (on average) over our existing SMA 1.3mm data which will be a significant jump forward. A related goal to resolving the cluster members is to characterize their SEDs using Bands 3 and 6. This demands that we obtain comparable uv-coverage at both Bands 3 and 6.
The other key science goal is to simultaneously spatially resolve the molecular outflows (to pinpoint the exciting sources and hence outflow size scale) and to accurately measure the full velocity extent of the outflow gas. Both of these are key to calculating the amount of outflow feedback. Based on the SMA data, we expect that the outflows will extend over much of the 60" extents of the mosaics, see Figure 2 (we will have 80" extent to 50% sensitivity), but we do not expect to see smooth structures larger than ~15" in extent. These two goals, coupled with the expected complex emission require a wide range of spatial scales to achieve good image fidelity. Outflow tracers with a wide range of excitation, optical depth, and critical density have been selected in Bands 3 and 6 so that all parts of the outflows can be detected. Thus for this goal as well, comparable uv-coverage is needed for both bands.
The following array combinations give the requisite and comparable range of spatial scales: Band 3: C36-4 (1" resolution, naturally-weighted) combined with C36-1 (LAS 25.3") Band 6: C36-2 (1" resolution, naturally-weighted) combined with 7m-array (LAS 18.6")

With this proposal we seek 0.15 K rms noise in a 2.5 km/s channel in a 1" beam. In line-free channels, the average spectral rms noise of our SMA data with a beam of 3.2"x2.2" is 0.2 K per 2.5 km/s channel. However, the rms noise of the SMA cubes in line-bright channels are significantly dynamic range limited, never exceeding S/N > 25 (compared to the few hundred possible in the brightest CO channels) due to the poor uv-coverage afforded by a 6-8 element array coupled with the complex emission morphology (see Fig 2). With the excellent uv-coverage and spatial dynamic range afforded by ALMA we expect to achieve a dynamic range of at least 100 which will allow us to detect the low-lying CO that may contribute significant mass. This level of sensitivity will also ensure that we are detecting the maximum extrema of the high velocity but weak CO emission. This level of sensitivity is also required to detect the much less optically thick CO isotopologues (13CO, C18O), and the wide range of other less abundant shock tracing lines within the spectral setup (SiO, H2CO, SO, CH3OH, HC3N). These rarer lines are essential to trace the outflows back to their exciting sources as the more abundant CO and 13CO will be confused with residual core emission near the systemic velocity.
The requested velocity resolution of 2.5 km/s will be sufficient to resolve the clumpy outflow emission which we expect to have local linewidths of ~10 km/s, though many 10s of km/s wide over its total extent. This resolution will also help to separate the quiescent core emission from the outflow emission near the systemic velocity.
The proposed set up includes 1x1.875 GHz spws in each sideband. For Band 6 we assume that 1 GHz of continuum bandwidth will be available per 1.875 GHz spw. To better constrain the SEDs we plan to image the continuum in each sideband separately. With the time set to achieve the requested spectral rms noise, we will be able to obtain continuum rms noise levels of 0.26 and 0.29 mJy/beam for the LSB and USB respectively. These noise levels will allow us to go at least 10x deeper than for the SMA data (see Table 1), with a factor of 7 improvement in beam area. The peak intensities from the 3.2"x2.2" 1.3mm SMA data are given in Table 1, and range from 114 to 741 mJy/beam. These values will likely be reduced by the factor of 7 decrease in beam area for peak ALMA intensities in the 16 to 106 mJy/beam range for S/N levels of 50 to 365. Thus, the known bright continuum sources will be easily resolved and detected at the proposed sensitivity, and will be plenty bright enough to self-calibrate which will allow us to acheive the high roposed dynamic range values. This is essential as the dramatic improvement in rms noise will allow us to detect as yet undiscovered lower mass members of the clusters.

In 3 basebands we have used the wideband FDM mode. This is essential to remove strong spectral lines from the continuum. These targets are relatively line rich and we expect line widths of several km/s. Thus the ~3.4 km/s spectral resolution afforded by this setup will be adequate to detect and remove contaminating line emission. Additionally there may be a few lines that show significant ouflow emission up to several 10s of km/s wide (SO, HC3N) for which this spectral resolution will also allow detailed mapping. These noise levels will allow us to go at least 10x deeper than for the SMA data (see Table 1), with a factor of 7 improvement in beam area. The peak intensities from the 3.2"x2.2" 1.3mm SMA data are given in Table 1, and range from 114 to 741 mJy/beam. These values will likely be reduced by the factor of 7 decrease in beam area for peak ALMA intensities in the 16 to 106 mJy/beam range for S/N levels of 50 to 365. Thus, the known bright continuum sources will be easily resolved and detected at the proposed sensitivity, and will be plenty bright enough to self-calibrate which will allow us to acheive the high roposed dynamic range values. This is essential as the dramatic improvement in rms noise will allow us to detect as yet undiscovered lower mass members of the clusters.

In 3 basebands we have used the wideband FDM mode. This is essential to remove strong spectral lines from the continuum. These targets are relatively line rich and we expect line widths of several km/s. Thus the ~3.4 km/s spectral resolution afforded by this setup will be adequate to detect and remove contaminating line emission. Additionally there may be a few lines that show significant ouflow emission up to several 10s of km/s wide (SO, HC3N) for which this spectral resolution will also allow detailed mapping. To reduce the data rate, we set the spectral averaging to 2 for these 3 wideband windows since this does not affect the final velocity resolution.
We also placed 2 narrow spws in the 4th baseband to cover 7 hyperfine transitions of CN (1-0). The expected line width for these transitions is expected to be 2-3 km/s. The velocity resolution for these narrow spws is 0.37 km/s, adequate to resolve the lines.

A key goal of this proposal is to spatially resolve the cluster members. The typical separation of massive cluster members is ~5000 AU. The range of distances to the ALMA EGO sample is 1.13 to 4.8 kpc. Thus an angular resolution of 1" provides a resolution better than 4800 AU for all of the targets and an improvment in beam area of a factor of 7 (on average) over our existing SMA 1.3mm data which will be a significant jump forward. A related goal to resolving the cluster members is to characterize their SEDs using Bands 3 and 6. This demands that we obtain comparable uv-coverage at both Bands 3 and 6.
The other key science goal is to simultaneously spatially resolve the molecular outflows (to pinpoint the exciting sources and hence outflow size scale) and to accurately measure the full velocity extent of the outflow gas. Both of these are key to calculating the amount of outflow feedback. Based on the SMA data, we expect that the outflows will extend over much of the 60" extents of the mosaics, see Figure 2 (we will have 80" extent to 50% sensitivity), but we do not expect to see smooth structures larger than ~15" in extent. These two goals, coupled with the expected complex emission require a wide range of spatial scales to achieve good image fidelity. Outflow tracers with a wide range of excitation, optical depth, and critical density have been selected in Bands 3 and 6 so that all parts of the outflows can be detected. Thus for this goal as well, comparable uv-coverage is needed for both bands.
The following array combinations give the requisite and comparable range of spatial scales: Band 3: C36-4 (1" resolution, naturally-weighted) combined with C36-1 (LAS 25.3") Band 6: C36-2 (1" resolution, naturally-weighted) combined with 7m-array (LAS 18.6")

For Band 3, we would like to resolve the emission in each of the "bright" SMA 1.3 mm sources of size ~5" coincident with the EGOs. The peak intensities at 1.3 mm for a 3.2"x2.2" beam are given in Table 2. We would like to independently detect the sources in the upper and lower sidebands of the Band 3 setup in order to better constrain the SED. For the LSB the bandwidth is 2x1.875 GHz, of which we assume 75% will be line-free for a LSBcont_BW=2.8 GHz at 100.5 GHz. In USB there is 1x1.875*75%, or USBcont_BW=1.4GHz at 111.5 GHz. Assuming a 1" beam, and a very conservative assumption of Gaussian emission, the observed ALMA peak emission will be less by the reduction in beam area: 7 (the same reduction holds if the source instead breaks up into 7 pieces - a more likely scenario given past experience than the sources being single Gaussians at the SMA resolution). Assuming the most conservative B3 to B6 spectral index of 4 (only dust, beta=2) the reduction factor for LSB is 28 and for USB 18. Together these assumptions yield at minimum an 8sigma detection in B3 LSB for the weakest of the EGOs in the sample (SMA 1.3mm peak 114 mJy/beam, G18.89-0.47).
Additionally, at the sensitivity level of the current SMA data, most of the EGOs also show a few weaker, much more compact 1.3mm sources in the FOV, with peak intensities of ~20 mJy/beam. These are much less likely to break up into multiple sources as they are already unresolved in the SMA beam. Scaling only by the factor of 28 for the B3 LSB dust spectral index, we predict typical B3 LSB intensities of 0.7 mJy/beam or S/N~10sigma. Thus, we should also be able to reach compact sources at 5 sigma as weak as 0.35 mJy/beam at 101.5 GHz.
The requested B3 sensitivity is driven by the continuum considerations above. However, we also put two narrow spws that cover 7 CN (1-0) hyperfine transitions. This is ancillary science that will allow us to determine the basic properties of the CN emission (peak emission location within the mosaic and linewidth) to prepare for future ALMA Zeeman magnetic field observations. With an assumed spectral resolution of 0.5 km/s, the spectral rms will be 11.3 mJy/beam or 1.1 K. This will be adequate to detect the expected CN line peak emission of ~10 K. Additionally, the emission from the 7 hyperfine transitions can be combined for improved sensitivity.

The datarate is only slightly above 12 MB/s (12.21 MB/s). As described above, the requested level of spectral resolution is needed to resolve the lines and for the continuum to remove the line contamination. A factor of 2 spectral averaging has been selected since that does not impact the velocity resolution.

The correlator has been configured to cover in one tuning as many shock/outflow tracing lines in Band 6 as possible. The simultaneous observation of 12CO and 13CO requires that they be observed with narrow spws. Even so, their bandwidth (300 km/s) is wide enough to encompass the extent of CO emission, see Table 1. However, it is notable that this narrow width precludes the most efficient observing scheme -- only sources with very similar LSRK velocities can be observed together due to this narrow bandwidth. An additional narrow spw with 0.4 km/s channels covers N2D+ which for lower mass sources in the clusters may be as narrow as a few km/s. Two 1.875 GHz wide spws cover other shock tracing lines, most importantly SiO, H2CO, SO, CH3OH, HC3N. We expect that the shock tracing lines will be about 10 km/s wide locally, though spanning many 10s of km/s in full extent. We plan to image the shock tracing lines with 2.5 km/s resolution to provide four spectral elements across local shock features. Lines that can trace the thermal gas in the core like C18O can be imaged at the best spectral resolution of ~1.5 km/s which will be adequate based on our existing ammonia data (see Figure 1).

A key goal of this proposal is to spatially resolve the cluster members. The typical separation of massive cluster members is ~5000 AU. The range of distances to the ALMA EGO sample is 1.13 to 4.8 kpc. Thus an angular resolution of 1" provides a resolution better than 4800 AU for all of the targets and an improvment in beam area of a factor of 7 (on average) over our existing SMA 1.3mm data which will be a significant jump forward. A related goal to resolving the cluster members is to characterize their SEDs using Bands 3 and 6. This demands that we obtain comparable uv-coverage at both Bands 3 and 6.
The other key science goal is to simultaneously spatially resolve the molecular outflows (to pinpoint the exciting sources and hence outflow size scale) and to accurately measure the full velocity extent of the outflow gas. Both of these are key to calculating the amount of outflow feedback. Based on the SMA data, we expect that the outflows will extend over much of the 60" extents of the mosaics, see Figure 2 (we will have 80" extent to 50% sensitivity), but we do not expect to see smooth structures larger than ~15" in extent. These two goals, coupled with the expected complex emission require a wide range of spatial scales to achieve good image fidelity. Outflow tracers with a wide range of excitation, optical depth, and critical density have been selected in Bands 3 and 6 so that all parts of the outflows can be detected. Thus for this goal as well, comparable uv-coverage is needed for both bands.
The following array combinations give the requisite and comparable range of spatial scales: Band 3: C36-4 (1" resolution, naturally-weighted) combined with C36-1 (LAS 25.3") Band 6: C36-2 (1" resolution, naturally-weighted) combined with 7m-array (LAS 18.6")

With this proposal we seek 0.15 K rms noise in a 2.5 km/s channel in a 1" beam. In line-free channels, the average spectral rms noise of our SMA data with a beam of 3.2"x2.2" is 0.2 K per 2.5 km/s channel. However, the rms noise of the SMA cubes in line-bright channels are significantly dynamic range limited, never exceeding S/N > 25 (compared to the few hundred possible in the brightest CO channels) due to the poor uv-coverage afforded by a 6-8 element array coupled with the complex emission morphology (see Fig 2). With the excellent uv-coverage and spatial dynamic range afforded by ALMA we expect to achieve a dynamic range of at least 100 which will allow us to detect the low-lying CO that may contribute significant mass. This level of sensitivity will also ensure that we are detecting the maximum extrema of the high velocity but weak CO emission. This level of sensitivity is also required to detect the much less optically thick CO isotopologues (13CO, C18O), and the wide range of other less abundant shock tracing lines within the spectral setup (SiO, H2CO, SO, CH3OH, HC3N). These rarer lines are essential to trace the outflows back to their exciting sources as the more abundant CO and 13CO will be confused with residual core emission near the systemic velocity.
The requested velocity resolution of 2.5 km/s will be sufficient to resolve the clumpy outflow emission which we expect to have local linewidths of ~10 km/s, though many 10s of km/s wide over its total extent. This resolution will also help to separate the quiescent core emission from the outflow emission near the systemic velocity.
The proposed set up includes 1x1.875 GHz spws in each sideband. For Band 6 we assume that 1 GHz of continuum bandwidth will be available per 1.875 GHz spw. To better constrain the SEDs we plan to image the continuum in each sideband separately. With the time set to achieve the requested spectral rms noise, we will be able to obtain continuum rms noise levels of 0.26 and 0.29 mJy/beam for the LSB and USB respectively. These noise levels will allow us to go at least 10x deeper than for the SMA data (see Table 1), with a factor of 7 improvement in beam area. The peak intensities from the 3.2"x2.2" 1.3mm SMA data are given in Table 1, and range from 114 to 741 mJy/beam. These values will likely be reduced by the factor of 7 decrease in beam area for peak ALMA intensities in the 16 to 106 mJy/beam range for S/N levels of 50 to 365. Thus, the known bright continuum sources will be easily resolved and detected at the proposed sensitivity, and will be plenty bright enough to self-calibrate which will allow us to acheive the high roposed dynamic range values. This is essential as the dramatic improvement in rms noise will allow us to detect as yet undiscovered lower mass members of the clusters.

In 3 basebands we have used the wideband FDM mode. This is essential to remove strong spectral lines from the continuum. These targets are relatively line rich and we expect line widths of several km/s. Thus the ~3.4 km/s spectral resolution afforded by this setup will be adequate to detect and remove contaminating line emission. Additionally there may be a few lines that show significant ouflow emission up to several 10s of km/s wide (SO, HC3N) for which this spectral resolution will also allow detailed mapping. To reduce the data rate, we set the spectral averaging to 2 for these 3 wideband windows since this does not affect the final velocity resolution.
We also placed 2 narrow spws in the 4th baseband to cover 7 hyperfine transitions of CN (1-0). The expected line width for these transitions is expected to be 2-3 km/s. The velocity resolution for these narrow spws is 0.37 km/s, adequate to resolve the lines.

For Band 3, we would like to resolve the emission in each of the "bright" SMA 1.3 mm sources of size ~5" coincident with the EGOs. The datarate is only slightly above 12 MB/s (12.21 MB/s). As described above, the requested level of spectral resolution is needed to resolve the lines and for the continuum to remove the line contamination. A factor of 2 spectral averaging has been selected since that does not impact the velocity resolution.

The correlator has been configured to cover in one tuning as many shock/outflow tracing lines in Band 6 as possible. The simultaneous observation of 12CO and 13CO requires that they be observed with narrow spws. Even so, their bandwidth (300 km/s) is wide enough to encompass the extent of CO emission, see Table 1. We plan to image the shock tracing lines with 2.5 km/s resolution to provide four spectral elements across local shock features. Lines that can trace the thermal gas in the core like C18O can be imaged at the best spectral resolution of ~1.5 km/s which will be adequate based on our existing ammonia data (see Figure 1).

A key goal of this proposal is to spatially resolve the cluster members. The typical separation of massive cluster members is ~5000 AU. The range of distances to the ALMA EGO sample is 1.13 to 4.8 kpc. Thus an angular resolution of 1" provides a resolution better than 4800 AU for all of the targets and an improvment in beam area of a factor of 7 (on average) over our existing SMA 1.3mm data which will be a significant jump forward. A related goal to resolving the cluster members is to characterize their SEDs using Bands 3 and 6. This demands that we obtain comparable uv-coverage at both Bands 3 and 6.
The other key science goal is to simultaneously spatially resolve the molecular outflows (to pinpoint the exciting sources and hence outflow size scale) and to accurately measure the full velocity extent of the outflow gas. Both of these are key to calculating the amount of outflow feedback. Based on the SMA data, we expect that the outflows will extend over much of the 60" extents of the mosaics, see Figure 2 (we will have 80" extent to 50% sensitivity), but we do not expect to see smooth structures larger than ~15" in extent. With this proposal we seek 0.15 K rms noise in a 2.5 km/s channel in a 1" beam. In line-free channels, the average spectral rms noise of our SMA data with a beam of 3.2"x2.2" is 0.2 K per 2.5 km/s channel. However, the rms noise of the SMA cubes in line-bright channels are significantly dynamic range limited, never exceeding S/N > 25 (compared to the few hundred possible in the brightest CO channels) due to the poor uv-coverage afforded by a 6-8 element array coupled with the complex emission morphology (see Fig 2). With the excellent uv-coverage and spatial dynamic range afforded by ALMA we expect to achieve a dynamic range of at least 100 which will allow us to detect the low-lying CO that may contribute significant mass. This level of sensitivity will also ensure that we are detecting the maximum extrema of the high velocity but weak CO emission. This level of sensitivity is also required to detect the much less optically thick CO isotopologues (13CO, C18O), and the wide range of other less abundant shock tracing lines within the spectral setup (SiO, H2CO, SO, CH3OH, HC3N). These rarer lines are essential to trace the outflows back to their exciting sources as the more abundant CO and 13CO will be confused with residual core emission near the systemic velocity.
The requested velocity resolution of 2.5 km/s will be sufficient to resolve the clumpy outflow emission which we expect to have local linewidths of ~10 km/s, though many 10s of km/s wide over its total extent. This resolution will also help to separate the quiescent core emission from the outflow emission near the systemic velocity.
The proposed set up includes 1x1.875 GHz spws in each sideband. For Band 6 we assume that 1 GHz of continuum bandwidth will be available per 1.875 GHz spw. To better constrain the SEDs we plan to image the continuum in each sideband separately. With the time set to achieve the requested spectral rms noise, we will be able to obtain continuum rms noise levels of 0.26 and 0.29 mJy/beam for the LSB and USB respectively. These noise levels will allow us to go at least 10x deeper than for the SMA data (see Table 1), with a factor of 7 improvement in beam area. The peak intensities from the 3.2"x2.2" 1.3mm SMA data are given in Table 1, and range from 114 to 741 mJy/beam. These values will likely be reduced by the factor of 7 decrease in beam area for peak ALMA intensities in the 16 to 106 mJy/beam range for S/N levels of 50 to 365. Thus, the known bright continuum sources will be easily resolved and detected at the proposed sensitivity, and will be plenty bright enough to self-calibrate which will allow us to acheive the high roposed dynamic range values. This is essential as the dramatic improvement in rms noise will allow us to detect as yet undiscovered lower mass members of the clusters.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Past observations indicate that the formation of clusters containing massive stars includes an evolutionary phase where multiple outflows are being driven by a population of actively-accreting protostars. Numerical simulations of this protocluster phase suggest that the momentum feedback from outflows serves to maintain turbulence in the parent clump, while the energy feedback is insufficient to disrupt it. These combined effects have a strong impact on the star formation rate, the mass of stars that are formed and ultimately the IMF. To quantify the level of feedback observationally, we propose to survey a unique sample of 8 massive protoclusters rigorously identified through multi-wavelength studies as being in a specific evolutionary state in which outflows dominate their infrared appearance. Our initial SMA survey at 3" resolution found CO velocity extents up to +/-80 km/s with complex morphology indicative of overlapping outflows, consistent with multiple active protostars. The sensitivity of ALMA will allow us to measure the optical depth in the outflow gas, calculate accurate values for the total feedback, and locate and study the properties of the driving sources.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
